<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Indicate by check mark whether the registrants (1) have filed all reports required to be filed by Section 13 or 15(d) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 during the preceding 12 months (or for such shorter period that the registrants were required to file such reports) and (2) have been subject to such filing requirements for the past 90&nbsp;days. Yes&nbsp;</font><font color=#000000><font face="Wingdings 2">&#083;</font></font><font color=#000000>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;No&nbsp;</font><font color=#000000><font face="Wingdings 2">&#163;</font></font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>As of July 27, 2005, Public Service Enterprise Group Incorporated had outstanding 239,023,863 shares of its sole class of Common Stock, without par value.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>As of July 27, 2005, Public Service Electric and Gas Company had issued and outstanding 132,450,344 shares of Common Stock, without nominal or par value, all of which were privately held, beneficially and of record by Public Service Enterprise Group Incorporated.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>PSEG Power LLC and PSEG Energy Holdings L.L.C. are wholly owned subsidiaries of Public Service Enterprise Group Incorporated and meet the conditions set forth in General Instruction H(1) (a) and (b) of Form&nbsp;10-Q and are filing their respective Quarterly Reports on Form&nbsp;10-Q with the reduced disclosure format authorized by General Instruction H.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Indicate by check mark whether each registrant is an accelerated filer (as defined in Rule&nbsp;12b-2 of the Exchange Act).</font></p>

<p align=center><b><font color=#000000><a name='Forward'>FORWARD-LOOKING STATEMENTS</a></font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Certain of the matters discussed in this report constitute &ldquo;forward-looking statements&rdquo; within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Such forward-looking statements are subject to risks and uncertainties, which could cause actual results to differ materially from those anticipated. Such statements are based on management&#39;s beliefs as well as assumptions made by and information currently available to management. When used herein, the words &ldquo;will,&rdquo; &ldquo;anticipate,&rdquo; &ldquo;intend,&rdquo; &ldquo;estimate,&rdquo; &ldquo;believe,&rdquo; &ldquo;expect,&rdquo; &ldquo;plan,&rdquo; &ldquo;hypothetical,&rdquo; &ldquo;potential,&rdquo; &ldquo;forecast,&rdquo; &ldquo;project,&rdquo; variations of such words and similar expressions are intended to identify forward-looking
statements. Public Service Enterprise Group Incorporated (PSEG), Public Service Electric and Gas Company (PSE&amp;G), PSEG Power LLC (Power) and PSEG Energy Holdings L.L.C. (Energy Holdings) undertake no obligation to publicly update or revise any forward-looking statements, whether as a result of new information, future events or otherwise. The following review should not be construed as a complete list of factors that could effect forward-looking statements.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>In addition to any assumptions and other factors referred to specifically in connection with such forward-looking statements discussed above, factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from those contemplated in any forward-looking statements include, among others, the following:</font></p>

<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>PSEG and Power</font></b></p>

Each of PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings expressly disclaims any obligation or undertaking to release publicly any updates or revisions to these forward-looking statements to reflect events or circumstances that occur or arise or are anticipated to occur
or arise after the date hereof. In making any investment decision regarding PSEG&#39;s, PSE&amp;G&#39;s, Power&#39;s and Energy Holdings&#39; securities, PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings are not making, and you should not infer, any representation about the likely existence of any particular future set of facts or circumstances. The forward-looking statements contained in this report are intended to qualify for the safe harbor provisions of Section 27A of the Securities Act of 1933, as amended, and Section 21E of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, as amended.</font></p>

<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=center><b><font color=#000000><a name='Notes'>NOTES TO CONDENSED CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS</a><br>
(UNAUDITED)</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>This combined Form&nbsp;10-Q is separately filed by Public Service Enterprise Group Incorporated (PSEG), Public Service Electric and Gas Company (PSE&amp;G), PSEG Power LLC (Power) and PSEG Energy Holdings L.L.C. (Energy Holdings). Information contained herein relating to any individual company is filed by such company on its own behalf. PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings each make representations only as to itself and make no representations as to any other company.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000><a name='Note1'>Note 1. Organization and Basis of Presentation</a></font></b></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>Organization</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSEG</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>PSEG has four principal direct wholly owned subsidiaries: PSE&amp;G, Power, Energy Holdings and PSEG Services Corporation (Services).</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>As previously disclosed, on December 20, 2004, PSEG entered into an agreement and plan of merger (Merger Agreement) with Exelon Corporation (Exelon), a public utility holding company registered under the Public Utility Holding Company Act of 1935 (PUHCA), which is headquartered in Chicago, Illinois, whereby PSEG will be merged with and into Exelon (Merger). Under the Merger Agreement, each share of PSEG Common Stock will be converted into 1.225 shares of Exelon Common Stock.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>On June&nbsp;30, 2005, the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC) approved the Merger.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The Merger Agreement has been unanimously approved by both companies&#39; Boards of Directors. On July&nbsp;19, 2005, shareholders of PSEG voted to approve the Merger and on July&nbsp;22, 2005, shareholders of Exelon voted to approve the issuance of common shares to PSEG shareholders to effect the Merger. Completion of the Merger is subject to approval by a number of governmental authorities, which may impose conditions on completion of the Merger, require changes to the terms of the Merger or fail to approve the Merger.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSE&amp;G</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>PSE&amp;G is an operating public utility engaged principally in the transmission of electric energy and distribution of electric energy and natural gas service in certain areas of New Jersey. PSE&amp;G is subject to regulation by the New Jersey Board of Public Utilities (BPU) and the FERC.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>PSE&amp;G also owns PSE&amp;G Transition Funding LLC (Transition Funding), a bankruptcy-remote entity that purchased certain intangible transition property from PSE&amp;G and issued certain transition bonds secured by such property.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Power</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Power is a multi-regional, wholesale energy supply company that integrates its generating asset operations with its wholesale energy, fuel supply, energy trading and marketing and risk management function through three principal direct wholly owned subsidiaries: PSEG Nuclear LLC (Nuclear), PSEG Fossil LLC (Fossil) and PSEG Energy Resources &amp; Trade LLC (ER&amp;T). Nuclear and Fossil own and operate generation and generation-related facilities. ER&amp;T is responsible for the&nbsp;day-to-day management of the portfolio. Fossil, Nuclear and ER&amp;T are subject to regulation by the FERC and Nuclear is subject to regulation by the Nuclear Regulatory Commission (NRC).</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Energy Holdings has two principal direct wholly owned subsidiaries: PSEG Global L.L.C. (Global), which owns and operates international and domestic projects engaged in the generation and distribution of energy, including power production facilities and electric distribution companies and PSEG Resources L.L.C. (Resources), which has primarily invested in energy-related leveraged leases. Energy</font></p>
<p align=center>16</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=center><b><font color=#000000>NOTES TO CONDENSED CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS<br>
(UNAUDITED)</font></b></p>
<p align=left><font color=#000000>Holdings also owns Enterprise Group Development Corporation (EGDC), a commercial real estate property management business.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Services</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Services provides management and administrative services to PSEG and its subsidiaries. These include accounting, legal, communications, human resources, information technology, treasury and financial services, investor relations, stockholder services, real estate, environmental, health and safety, insurance, risk management, tax, library, records and information services, security, corporate secretarial and certain planning, budgeting and forecasting services. Services charges PSEG and its subsidiaries for the cost of work performed and services provided pursuant to the terms and conditions of intercompany service agreements.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The respective financial statements included herein have been prepared pursuant to the rules and regulations of the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) for Quarterly Reports on Form&nbsp;10-Q. Certain information and note disclosures normally included in financial statements prepared in accordance with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States (GAAP) have been condensed or omitted pursuant to such rules and regulations. These Condensed Consolidated Financial Statements and Notes to Condensed Consolidated Financial Statements (Notes) should be read in conjunction with, and update and supplement matters discussed in PSEG&#39;s, PSE&amp;G&#39;s, Power&#39;s and Energy Holdings&#39; respective Annual Reports on Form&nbsp;10-K for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2004 and Quarterly Reports on Form&nbsp;10-Q
for the quarter ended March&nbsp;31, 2005.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The unaudited condensed consolidated financial information furnished herein reflects all adjustments which are, in the opinion of management, necessary to fairly state the results for the interim periods presented. All such adjustments are of a normal recurring nature. The year-end Condensed Consolidated Balance Sheets were derived from the audited Consolidated Financial Statements included in the Annual Report on Form&nbsp;10-K for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2004. Certain reclassifications of prior period data have been made to conform with the current presentation.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>Pension and Other Postretirement Benefits (OPEB)</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSEG</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>PSEG sponsors several qualified and nonqualified pension plans and OPEB plans covering PSEG and its participating affiliates&#39; current and former employees who meet certain eligibility criteria. As a result of union negotiations, certain changes to the pension plans and OPEB plans were made in March 2005. These include increases to the benefit formula in the pension plan, supplemental pension benefits and certain other changes to OPEB. Substantially all changes to the pension plans became effective May&nbsp;1, 2005 and the majority of changes to the OPEB plans will be effective January&nbsp;1, 2006 or July&nbsp;1, 2006. The pension benefits and OPEB obligations, as well as the asset values, have been re-measured as of March&nbsp;31, 2005 to reflect the effect of the plan changes. The annual net periodic pension benefit
costs for 2005 will increase by approximately $2 million or 2% and the 2005 annual net OPEB costs will increase by approximately $11 million or 11% from costs that would have been expensed in 2005 had the plans&#39; provisions remained unchanged. The new projected pension benefit obligation and accumulated benefit obligation as of March&nbsp;31, 2005 were $3.5 billion and $2.9 billion, respectively. The new OPEB accumulated benefit obligation as of March&nbsp;31, 2005 was $1.1 billion.</font></p>
<p align=center>17</p>

<td bgcolor=#e5ffff>&nbsp;</td>

<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>Stock Compensation</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSEG</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>PSEG applies Accounting Principles Board (APB) Opinion No. 25, &ldquo;Accounting for Stock Issued to Employees&rdquo; (APB 25) and related interpretations in accounting for stock-based compensation plans. Accordingly, no compensation cost has been recognized for fixed stock option grants since the exercise price of the stock options equaled the market price of the underlying stock on the date of grant.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>PSEG also grants restricted stock and performance units to certain key executives and employees. In 2005, 270,000 shares of restricted stock were granted under the 2004 Long-Term Incentive Plan to certain key executives and employees. These shares vest on a staggered schedule beginning in January 2006 and become fully vested in January 2008, except for accelerated vesting in the case of retirement or involuntary separation without cause. Compensation expense on the restricted stock grants is recorded ratably over the vesting period. Compensation expense for performance units is measured and recognized once it can be determined that the performance goals will be achieved.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The following table illustrates the effect on Net (Loss) Income and Earnings Per Share if PSEG had applied the fair value recognition provisions of Statement of Financial Accounting Standards (SFAS) No. 123, &ldquo;Accounting for Stock-Based Compensation,&rdquo; (SFAS 123) to stock-based employee compensation:</font></p>
<p align=center>18</p>

<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>See Note 4. Earnings Per Share for further information.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000><a Name='Note2'>Note 2. Recent Accounting Standards</a></font></b></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>SFAS No. 154, &ldquo;Accounting Changes and Error Corrections&rdquo; (SFAS 154)</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>In May 2005, the Financial Accounting Standards Board (FASB) issued SFAS 154, which is effective for accounting changes and corrections of errors made in fiscal years beginning after December 15, 2005. SFAS 154 requires retrospective application to prior periods&#39; financial statements of voluntary changes in accounting principles unless it is impracticable to determine either the period-specific effects or the cumulative effect of the change.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>SFAS 154 requires that a change in depreciation, amortization or depletion method for long-lived non-financial assets be accounted for as a change in accounting estimate effected by a change in accounting principle.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>SFAS No. 123R, &ldquo;Share-Based Payment, an amendment of SFAS No. 123 and 95&rdquo; (SFAS 123R)</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSEG</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>In December 2004, the FASB issued SFAS 123R, which revises SFAS 123 and supersedes APB 25 and its related implementation guidance. SFAS 123R focuses primarily on accounting for transactions in which an entity obtains employee services in share-based payment transactions. SFAS 123R is effective for the first annual reporting period beginning after June 15, 2005 and requires entities to recognize stock compensation expense for awards of equity instruments to employees based on the grant-date fair value of those awards (with limited exceptions). PSEG is evaluating the two proposed methods of adoption allowed by SFAS 123R and does not believe that the adoption of SFAS 123R will have a material effect on its financial statements.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>FASB Interpretation No. (FIN) 47, &ldquo;Accounting for Conditional Asset Retirement Obligations&rdquo; (FIN&nbsp;47)</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>In March 2005, the FASB issued FIN 47 to clarify the term &ldquo;conditional asset retirement obligation&rdquo; as used in SFAS No. 143, &ldquo;Accounting for Asset Retirement Obligations.&rdquo; Conditional asset retirement obligation refers to a legal obligation to perform an asset retirement activity in which the</font></p>
<p align=center>19</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=center><b><font color=#000000>NOTES TO CONDENSED CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS<br>
(UNAUDITED)</font></b></p>
<p align=left><font color=#000000>timing and/or method of settlement are conditional on a future event that may or may not be within the control of the entity. The obligation to perform the asset retirement activity is unconditional even though uncertainty exists about the timing and/or method of settlement. Accordingly, an entity is required to recognize a liability for the fair value of a conditional asset retirement obligation if the fair value of the liability can be reasonably estimated. The fair value of a liability for the conditional asset retirement obligation should be recognized when incurred - generally, upon acquisition, construction, development and/or through the normal operation of the asset. Uncertainty about the timing and/or method of settlement should be factored into the measurement of the liability when sufficient information exists. FIN 47 also clarifies when an entity
would have sufficient information to reasonably estimate the fair value of an asset retirement obligation. FIN 47 is effective no later than the end of fiscal years ending after December 15, 2005. PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings are currently evaluating the impact that adoption of FIN 47 may have on their respective financial statements.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>Emerging Issues Task Force (EITF) Issue No.&nbsp;03-1, &ldquo;The Meaning of Other-Than-Temporary Impairment and Its Application to Certain Investments&rdquo; (EITF&nbsp;03-1)</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>EITF&nbsp;03-1 provides guidance for disclosure of impaired securities. On June 29, 2005, FASB withdrew EITF-03-1&#39;s provisions dealing with the measurement and recognition of other-than-temporary impairments. The remaining provisions of EITF&nbsp;03-1 that remain intact did not have a material impact on PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>FASB Staff Position (FSP) No.&nbsp;109-1, &ldquo;Application of FASB Statement No. 109, </font></b><i><b><font color=#000000>&ldquo;Accounting for Income Taxes&rdquo;</font></b></i><b><font color=#000000>, to the Tax Deduction on Qualified Production Activities Provided by the American Jobs Creation Act of 2004&rdquo; (FSP&nbsp;109-1)</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSEG, Power and Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>On December 21, 2004, the FASB issued FSP&nbsp;109-1, which was effective upon issuance, to provide guidance on the application of SFAS No. 109, &ldquo;Accounting for Income Taxes&rdquo; (SFAS 109), to the provision within the American Jobs Creation Act of 2004 (Jobs Act) that provides a tax deduction on qualified production activities. The Jobs Act includes a tax deduction of up to 9% (when fully phased-in) of the lesser of (a)&nbsp;&ldquo;qualified production activities income,&rdquo; as defined in the Jobs Act, or (b)&nbsp;taxable income (after the deduction for the utilization of any net operating loss carryforwards). The tax deduction is limited to 50% of&nbsp;W-2 wages paid by the taxpayer. FSP&nbsp;109-1 clarifies that the manufacturer&#39;s deduction provided for under the Jobs Act should be accounted for as a special
deduction in accordance with SFAS 109 and not as a tax rate reduction. PSEG, Power and Energy Holdings do not believe that neither the manufacturer&#39;s deduction, nor the application of FSP&nbsp;109-1, will have a material effect on their respective financial statements.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>FSP No.&nbsp;109-2, &ldquo;Accounting and Disclosure Guidance for the Foreign Earnings Repatriation Provision within the American Jobs Creation Act of 2004&rdquo; (FSP&nbsp;109-2)</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSEG and Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>On December 21, 2004, the FASB issued FSP&nbsp;109-2, which was effective upon issuance, to provide guidance on the application of the provision in the Jobs Act that allows a special one-time dividends received deduction on the repatriation of certain foreign earnings to a U.S. taxpayer, provided certain criteria are met. The Jobs Act provides a one-year window to repatriate earnings from foreign investments and claim a special 85% dividends received tax deduction on such distributions.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>As of June&nbsp;30, 2005, Global had approximately $400 million of unrepatriated earnings and profits associated with its foreign investments. Of this amount, approximately $170 million could reasonably be</font></p>
<p align=center>20</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=center><b><font color=#000000>NOTES TO CONDENSED CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS<br>
(UNAUDITED)</font></b></p>
<p align=left><font color=#000000>considered for repatriation as of June&nbsp;30, 2005 based on PSEG&#39;s degree of control of its international investments and the availability of funds and capital structures of such investments. In addition, Global&#39;s projections indicate that additional earnings could be generated by its international investments over the balance of 2005 that could increase the amount of funds that could reasonably be considered for repatriation in 2005 to $250 million. If a decision were made to repatriate such an amount, and those earnings and funds were available for repatriation, the tax expense associated with such repatriation would approximate $13 million. Whether PSEG will ultimately take advantage of this provision, all or in part, depends upon a number of factors including, but not limited to, evaluating the impact of Notice 2005-10 and Notice 2005-38 published
by the Internal Revenue Service (IRS), which discuss some of the rules pertaining to this deduction, as well as any future authoritative guidance. Global has made no change in its current intention to indefinitely reinvest accumulated earnings of its foreign subsidiaries.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>Proposed Standards</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSEG and Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>In July, the FASB issued proposed guidance concerning the accounting for uncertain tax positions and the accounting for the timing of cash flows relating to income taxes generated by leveraged lease transactions.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The proposal concerning uncertain tax positions would require that an uncertain tax position meet a probable recognition threshold based on the merits of the position in order for the benefit to be recognized in the financial statements. The proposal also addresses the accrual of interest and penalties related to tax uncertainties and the classification of liabilities on the balance sheet.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The proposal dealing with leveraged leases would require a lessor to perform a recalculation of a leveraged lease when there is a change in the timing of the realization of tax benefits generated by the lease. It would also require a lessor to re-evaluate classification as a leveraged lease when a recalculation of the lease is performed.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>If implemented in its present form, the impact on PSEG and Energy Holdings could be material.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000><a name='Note3'>Note 3. Discontinued Operations, Dispositions and Acquisitions</a></font></b></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>Discontinued Operations</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Power</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Waterford Generation Facility (Waterford)</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>On May 27, 2005, Power entered into an agreement to sell its electric generation facility located in Waterford, Ohio to a subsidiary of American Electric Power Company, Inc. (AEP). Since commencing construction of the project, the dramatic increase in natural gas prices relative to the price increase of coal and the failure to receive capacity compensation for the facility caused Power to consider alternatives for the project. After reviewing the alternatives in conjunction with other strategic and financial considerations, Power concluded that the value to be received from the sale of Waterford represented a means to accelerate the realization of the plant&#39;s value. The sale price for the facility and inventory is $220 million. The proceeds, together with anticipated reduction in tax liability, are approximately $300
million, which will be used to retire debt at Power and PSEG.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>In May 2005, Power recognized an estimated loss on disposal of $177 million, net of tax, for the initial write-down of its carrying amount of Waterford to its fair value less cost to sell.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The sale is subject to various regulatory approvals. It is anticipated that the transaction will close during the second half of 2005.</font></p>
<p align=center>21</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">

(UNAUDITED)</font></b></p>

<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Carthage Power Company (CPC)</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>In December 2003, Global entered into a definitive purchase and sale agreement related to the sale of its majority interest in CPC, which owns and operates a power plant located in Rades, Tunisia. In December 2003, Global also recognized an estimated loss on disposal of $23 million for the initial write-down of its carrying amount of CPC to its fair value less cost to sell. During the first quarter of 2004, Energy Holdings re-evaluated the carrying value of CPC&#39;s assets and liabilities and determined that an additional write-down to fair value of $2 million was required, which offset CPC&#39;s Net Income for the quarter ended March&nbsp;31, 2004. In May 2004, Global completed the sale of CPC for approximately $43 million in cash and recognized a gain on disposal of $5 million.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The operating results of CPC for the quarter and six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2004 are summarized below:</font></p>

<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td></tr>
</table>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>Dispositions</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Meiya Power Company Limited (MPC)</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>In December 2004, Global closed on the sale of its 50% equity interest in MPC to BTU Power Company for approximately $236 million, of which $100 million was paid in cash. The balance of approximately $136 million was provided in the form of a secured promissory note due on March&nbsp;31, 2005, which was later amended to extend the maturity date to April 2005 and increase the amount due. The sale resulted in an after-tax gain of approximately $2 million, which was recorded in the fourth</font></p>
<p align=center>22</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=center><b><font color=#000000>NOTES TO CONDENSED CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS<br>
(UNAUDITED)</font></b></p>
<p align=left><font color=#000000>quarter of 2004. Global received payments of $38 million and $99 million in January 2005 and April 2005, respectively, representing the full payment of the outstanding receivable.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Luz Del Sur S.A.A. (LDS)</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>In April 2004, Global sold a portion of its indirect ownership in LDS in the Lima stock exchange, reducing its ownership from 44% to 38% and received gross proceeds of approximately $31 million. Global realized a gain of approximately $5 million in the quarter and six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2004 related to the LDS sale which is recorded in Income from Equity Method Investments on the Condensed Consolidated Statements of Operations.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Solar Electric Generating Systems (SEGS) Projects</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>In January 2005, Resources and Global sold their minority limited partner interests in three SEGS projects for proceeds of approximately $7 million resulting in an after-tax gain of $4 million.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Dhofar Power Company S.A.O.C. (Dhofar Power)</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>In April 2005, Global sold a 35% interest in Dhofar Power through a public offering on the Omani stock exchange as required under the Concession Agreement, reducing Global&#39;s ownership in Dhofar Power from 81% to 46%. Net proceeds from the sale approximated $25 million, resulting in a modest gain. As a result, Global&#39;s investment in Dhofar Power has been accounted for under the equity method following the sale. Global&#39;s investment in Dhofar Power was $29 million and $53 million as of June&nbsp;30, 2005 and December&nbsp;31, 2004, respectively.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Resources</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Resources is the lessor of various aircraft to several domestic airlines, including a Boeing B767 aircraft to United Airlines (UAL). In December 2002, UAL filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection. On June 13, 2005, Resources received a notice from the Trustee under the UAL lease that the lenders had terminated the lease and repossessed the aircraft. Upon receipt of this notice, Resources recorded a $15 million charge, after-tax, in June 2005 to eliminate its carrying value of this investment since management believes that there will be insufficient proceeds to recover any of the recorded amount of the investment due to the termination.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>In January 2005, the KKR Fund sold its investment in KinderCare Learning Centers, Inc. and Resources received proceeds of approximately $17 million resulting in an after-tax gain of approximately $1 million.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>In March 2004, Resources entered into an agreement with Midwest Generation LLC, an indirect subsidiary of Edison Mission Energy, to terminate its lease investment in the Collins generating facility in Illinois. In March 2004, Resources recorded a $17 million&nbsp;pre-tax charge to reduce its carrying value of the Collins Lease. In April 2004, Resources closed on the termination of the lease agreement and received gross proceeds of approximately $184 million. The actual loss on the termination of the lease was $11 million, after-tax. As a result of the sale, Resources paid approximately $100 million in taxes.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>In January 2004, Resources terminated two lease transactions with Qantas Airways and China Eastern Airlines Co., Ltd resulting from the lessees exercising their respective purchase options. Resources received aggregate gross cash proceeds of approximately $45 million and recorded an after-tax gain of $4 million. As a result of the sale, Resources paid approximately $36 million in taxes.</font></p>
<p align=center>23</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=center><b><font color=#000000>NOTES TO CONDENSED CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS<br>
(UNAUDITED)</font></b></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>Acquisitions</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Texas Independent Energy, L.P. (TIE)</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>In July 2004, Global signed an agreement to acquire all of TECO Energy, Inc.&#39;s 50% equity interest in TIE for less than $1 million. With this purchase, Global owns 100% of TIE and consolidated this investment beginning July&nbsp;1, 2004.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Energy Holdings&#39; consolidated Operating Revenues for the quarter and six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2004 would have increased from $177 million to $335 million and from $390 million to $650 million, respectively, had the acquisition of TIE occurred at the beginning of 2004. Energy Holdings&#39; consolidated Net Income for the quarter and six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2004 would have increased from $26 million to $29 million and from $74 million to $76 million, respectively, had the acquisition of TIE occurred at the beginning of 2004. This pro forma information is presented for informational purposes only and is not necessarily indicative of the results of operations that actually would have been achieved had the acquisition been consummated as of that time, nor is it intended to be a projection of future results.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000><a name='Note4'>Note 4. Earnings Per Share (EPS)</a></font></b></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>PSEG</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Diluted EPS is calculated by dividing Net (Loss) Income by the weighted average number of shares of common stock outstanding, including shares issuable upon exercise of stock options outstanding under PSEG&#39;s stock option plans, upon payment of performance units and upon conversion of Participating Units. The following table shows the effect of these stock options, performance units and Participating Units on the weighted average number of shares outstanding used in calculating diluted EPS:</font></p>

<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>There were approximately 3.5 million and 3.1 million stock options excluded from the weighted average common shares calculation used for diluted EPS due to their antidilutive effect for the quarter and six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2004, respectively. No stock options had an antidilutive effect for the quarter and six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2005.</font></p>
<p align=center>24</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=center><b><font color=#000000>NOTES TO CONDENSED CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS<br>
(UNAUDITED)</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Dividend payments on common stock for the quarters ended June&nbsp;30, 2005 and 2004 were $0.56 and $0.55 per share, respectively, and totaled approximately $133 million and $130 million, respectively. Dividend payments on common stock for the six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2005 and 2004 were $1.12 and $1.10 per share, respectively, and totaled approximately $267 million and $260 million, respectively.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000><a name='Note5'>Note 5. Commitments and Contingent Liabilities</a></font></b></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>Guaranteed Obligations</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Power</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Power has unconditionally guaranteed payments by its subsidiary, ER&amp;T, in certain commodity-related transactions in the ordinary course of business. These payment guarantees were provided to counterparties in order to obtain credit under physical and financial agreements for gas, pipeline capacity, transportation, oil, electricity and related commodities and services. These Power payment guarantees support the current exposure, interest and other costs on sums due and payable by ER&amp;T under these agreements. Guarantees offered for trading and marketing cover lines of credit between entities and are often reciprocal in nature. The exposure between counterparties can move in either direction. The face value of the guarantees outstanding as of June&nbsp;30, 2005 and December&nbsp;31, 2004 was $1.7 billion and $1.6 billion,
respectively. In order for Power to incur a liability for the face value of the outstanding guarantees, ER&amp;T would have to fully utilize the credit granted to it by every counterparty to whom Power has provided a guarantee and all of ER&amp;T&#39;s contracts would have to be &ldquo;out-of-the-money&rdquo; (if the contracts are terminated, Power would owe money to the counterparties). The probability of all contracts at ER&amp;T being simultaneously &ldquo;out-of-the-money&rdquo; is highly unlikely. For this reason, the current exposure at any point in time is a more meaningful representation of the potential liability to Power under these guarantees. The current exposure consists of the net of accounts receivable and accounts payable and the forward value on open positions, less any margins posted. The current exposure from such liabilities was $488 million and $507 million as of June&nbsp;30,
2005 and December&nbsp;31, 2004, respectively. Of the $488 million exposure, $112 million was recorded on Power&#39;s Condensed Consolidated Balance Sheet as of June&nbsp;30, 2005. Of the $507 million exposure, $193 million was recorded on Power&#39;s Condensed Consolidated Balance Sheet as of December&nbsp;31, 2004.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Power is subject to collateral calls related to commodity contracts that are bilateral. As of June&nbsp;30, 2005, Power had recorded margin (cash) paid of approximately $69 million, including $15 million paid to PSE&amp;G, and margin (cash) received of approximately $38 million. Changes in energy prices cause a commensurate impact in collateral requirements for Power. As of June&nbsp;30, 2005, letters of credit issued by Power were outstanding in the amount of approximately $120 million in support of various contractual obligations, environmental liabilities and to satisfy trading collateral obligations.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>In connection with the management and optimization of Power&#39;s asset portfolio, ER&amp;T maintains agreements that require Power, as its guarantor under performance guarantees, to satisfy certain creditworthiness standards. In the event of a deterioration of Power&#39;s credit rating to below investment grade, many of these agreements allow the counterparty to demand that ER&amp;T provide performance assurance, generally in the form of a letter of credit or cash. As of June&nbsp;30, 2005, if Power were to lose its investment grade rating and assuming all counterparties to which ER&amp;T is &ldquo;out-of-the-money&rdquo; were contractually entitled to demand, and demanded, performance assurance, ER&amp;T could be required to post collateral in an amount equal to approximately $693 million. Providing this support would
increase Power&#39;s costs of doing business and could restrict the ability of ER&amp;T to manage and optimize Power&#39;s asset portfolio.</font></p>
<p align=center>25</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
