<p align=center>50</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=center><b><font color=#000000><a name='Management'>ITEM 2. MANAGEMENT&#39;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL<br>
CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS (MD&amp;A)</a></font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Following are the significant changes in or additions to information reported in the 2004 Annual Report on Form&nbsp;10-K affecting the consolidated financial condition and the results of operations. This discussion refers to the Condensed Consolidated Financial Statements (Statements) and the related Notes to Condensed Consolidated Financial Statements (Notes) and should be read in conjunction with such Statements and Notes.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>This combined MD&amp;A is separately filed by Public Service Enterprise Group Incorporated (PSEG), Public Service Electric and Gas Company (PSE&amp;G), PSEG Power LLC (Power), and PSEG Energy Holdings L.L.C. (Energy Holdings). Information contained herein relating to any individual company is filed by such company on its own behalf. PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings each make representations only as to itself and make no representations as to any other company.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000><a name='Pending'>PENDING MERGER</a></font></b></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>As previously disclosed, on December 20, 2004, PSEG entered into an agreement and plan of merger (Merger Agreement) with Exelon Corporation (Exelon), a public utility holding company registered under the Public Utility Holding Company Act of 1935 (PUHCA), which is headquartered in Chicago, Illinois, whereby PSEG and its subsidiaries will be merged with and into Exelon (Merger). Under the Merger Agreement, each share of PSEG Common Stock will be converted into 1.225 shares of Exelon Common Stock.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The Merger Agreement has been unanimously approved by both companies&#39; Boards of Directors. On July&nbsp;19, 2005, shareholders of PSEG voted to approve the Merger and on July&nbsp;22, 2005, shareholders of Exelon voted to approve the issuance of common shares to PSEG shareholders to effect the Merger.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Completion of the Merger is subject to approval by a number of governmental authorities, which may impose conditions on completion of the Merger, require changes to the terms of the Merger or fail to approve the Merger. The imposition of conditions or changes could have the effect of delaying completion of the Merger or imposing additional costs on or limiting the revenues of the combined company and/or the individual registrants following the Merger, any of which might have a material adverse effect on the combined company or the individual registrants following completion of the Merger. PSEG is committed to this proposed business combination; however, pending receipt of the various required approvals, which cannot be assured, PSEG intends to maintain a viable stand-alone business.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>In the first quarter of 2005, Exelon and PSEG filed applications or made filings with the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC), the New Jersey Board of Public Utilities (BPU), the Pennsylvania Public Utility Commission (PAPUC), the Nuclear Regulatory Commission (NRC), the New York Public Service Commission and the New Jersey Department of Environmental Protection (NJDEP). Exelon and PSEG also made the filings required under the Hart-Scott-Rodino Antitrust Improvements Act of 1976 (HSR) and Exelon filed a private letter ruling on the transfer of nuclear decommissioning funds with the Internal Revenue Service. Additional applications and notices will be filed in the upcoming months.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>On June&nbsp;30, 2005, the FERC voted to approve the Merger. The FERC determined that Exelon&#39;s and PSEG&#39;s proposed divestitures and other commitments in their original and supplemental filings with FERC, together with their answers to intervenors&#39; questions, met the public interest standard of the Federal Power Act. Exelon and PSEG have committed to divest 4,000 megawatts (MW) of intermediate and peaking generation facilities located primarily in eastern PJM Interconnection L.L.C. (PJM), and to &ldquo;virtually divest&rdquo; 2,600 MW of nuclear capacity by effectively transferring control of the output through sales to third parties.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The BPU scheduled public hearings starting in October 2005 in accordance with a timetable for the regulatory approval process that was established by an order of the Administrative Law Judge (ALJ) in</font></p>
<p align=center>51</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=left><font color=#000000>a proceeding on April&nbsp;5, 2005. The timetable provides for the ALJ to issue an initial decision by February&nbsp;26, 2006. Thereafter, pursuant to the provisions of the New Jersey Administrative Procedure Act, a decision from the BPU could reasonably be expected by March&nbsp;23, 2006. On June&nbsp;22, 2005, the BPU issued an oral decision stating that Exelon and PSEG will be required to prove that positive benefits flow to PSE&amp;G&#39;s customers as a result of the Merger, as well as no adverse impact to PSE&amp;G&#39;s competition, employees, customers, rates or reliability due to the Merger.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>On June&nbsp;30, 2005, intervenors filed testimony with the PAPUC regarding the proposed Merger in accordance with a timetable for the regulatory approval process in Pennsylvania that had been established by an order of the ALJ in a proceeding before the PAPUC. The current timetable provides for a hearing to commence on September&nbsp;12, 2005 and it is expected that the ALJ will issue an initial decision on or after November&nbsp;7, 2005. Thereafter, a decision from the PAPUC can be expected in January 2006 or February 2006 if the case is not settled at an earlier date.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>PSEG and Exelon expect to complete their responses to the information requests of the U.S. Department of Justice (DOJ) under the HSR Act in the near future. Once the DOJ has evaluated the information submitted by PSEG, Exelon and others, PSEG and Exelon expect to discuss any suggestions or remedies proposed by the DOJ.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The procedural schedules for both the PAPUC and BPU proceedings include opportunities for settlement discussions with the consumer advocacy groups and other interested parties during the course of the proceedings. Exelon and PSEG will endeavor to settle differences of opinion among the administrative litigants during the course of the proceedings if they are able to do so on satisfactory terms.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Based on the current status of the regulatory approval process, Exelon and PSEG expect that, assuming all other conditions to completion of the Merger are satisfied, the Merger should be completed in the first quarter of 2006 if the regulatory proceedings before the BPU and the PAPUC are settled and approved before the dates on which those state authorities are expected to rule on the Merger in the absence of a settlement, as discussed above. If early settlements are not reached and approved, then the parties expect that, assuming all other conditions are satisfied, the Merger should be completed in the second quarter of 2006.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Although Exelon and PSEG believe that the expectations as to timing for the closing of the Merger described above are reasonable, no assurances can be given as to the timing of the receipt of any required regulatory approvals or that all required approvals will be received. Inability to close the pending Merger with Exelon could have a material adverse effect on the financial condition, results of operations and cash flows of PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000><a name='Overview'>OVERVIEW</a></font></b></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Prior to the completion of the Merger, PSEG and Exelon, and their respective subsidiaries, will continue to operate as separate entities. The discussion contained in the MD&amp;A that follows relates solely to the current businesses of PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings and their respective expectations for future financial position, results of operations and cash flows, exclusive of any potential impacts from the proposed Merger.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>PSEG</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>PSEG&#39;s business consists of four reportable segments, which are PSE&amp;G, Power and the two direct subsidiaries of Energy Holdings: PSEG Global L.L.C. (Global) and PSEG Resources L.L.C. (Resources). The following is a discussion of the markets in which PSEG and its subsidiaries compete, the corporate strategy for the conduct of PSEG&#39;s businesses within these markets, significant events that have occurred during the first six months of 2005 and expectations for the full-year 2005 and beyond.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>For the six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2005, PSEG had Income from Continuing Operations of $393 million, or $1.62 diluted per share. PSEG continues to project Income from Continuing Operations for 2005 of $3.15 to $3.35 per share, reflecting improved operations at Power&#39;s generating facilities as</font></p>
<p align=center>52</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=left><font color=#000000>compared to 2004 and margin improvements through the expiration of existing sales contracts and the realization of current and anticipated higher market prices. PSEG expects Earnings Per Share in 2005 to be reduced by additional shares outstanding primarily due to the impact of the issuance of shares of common stock in November 2005 related to its participating equity securities. It is expected that costs associated with the proposed Merger could reduce 2005 results by as much as $0.10 to $0.15 per share, which is not included in the earnings projection noted above.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>PSE&amp;G</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>PSE&amp;G operates as an electric and gas public utility in New Jersey under cost-based regulation by the BPU for its distribution operations and by the FERC for its electric transmission and wholesale sales operations. Consequently, the earnings of PSE&amp;G are largely determined by the regulation of its rates by those agencies.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>PSE&amp;G provides electricity under two types of basic generation service (BGS) for customers who do not have a third party to source their electric supply requirements. BGS-Fixed Price (FP) provides supply for smaller commercial and residential customers at seasonally-adjusted fixed prices. PSE&amp;G&#39;s total BGS-FP load is approximately 8,600 MW. Approximately one-third of this total load is expected to be auctioned off each year for a three-year term. BGS-Commercial and Industrial Energy Price (CIEP) provides supply for larger customers at hourly PJM real-time market prices for a term of 12 months. BGS-FP and BGS-CIEP represent approximately 84% and 16%, respectively, of PSE&amp;G&#39;s current load.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>In February 2005, the BPU approved the results of New Jersey&#39;s annual BGS-FP and BGS-CIEP auctions and PSE&amp;G successfully secured contracts to provide the electricity requirements for its customers&#39; needs.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>BGS-FP rates change annually on June&nbsp;1 and are based on the average BGS price obtained at auction in the current year and two prior years. PSE&amp;G&#39;s current pricing is as follows:</font></p>
<table width=100% cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0 border=0><tr bgcolor=#ffffff>

</table>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The cost of energy supply for both gas and electricity is passed through by PSE&amp;G to its customers. On October&nbsp;5, 2004, the BPU approved a 3% increase, effective for one year commencing October&nbsp;1, 2004, in PSE&amp;G&#39;s residential gas commodity charge to cover the higher cost of natural gas. PSE&amp;G activated a 2.5% self-implementing increase effective February&nbsp;1, 2005. On May&nbsp;27, 2005, PSE&amp;G filed a motion with the BPU seeking increases in its residential gas commodity charge to cover the higher cost of natural gas and in its balancing charge to cover the cost of providing storage and peaking services. The combined increase, if approved, would be approximately 10.6% and would be effective October&nbsp;1, 2005.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>On April&nbsp;24, 2005, PSE&amp;G placed a new third bank of transformers into service at its Branchburg, New Jersey switching station. The operational limits, or ratings, of the existing banks of transformers had been reduced in March 2004 to avoid overheating in the units. Prior to the reduction, the two existing transformer banks had a capacity of approximately 1,600 MW. The additional bank increased the total capacity at Branchburg to 2,150 MW.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>For the six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2005, PSE&amp;G had Net Income of $167 million. PSE&amp;G expects Income from Continuing Operations to range from $325 million to $345 million for 2005, based on normal weather conditions, expected growth in electricity and natural gas sales and productivity gains, partially offset by operating cost increases.</font></p>
<p align=center>53</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>Power</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Power is an electric generation and wholesale energy marketing and trading company that focuses on the generation market extending from Maine to the Carolinas and the Atlantic Coast to Indiana (Region). Power&#39;s principal operating subsidiaries, PSEG Fossil LLC (Fossil), PSEG Nuclear LLC (Nuclear) and PSEG Energy Resources &amp; Trade LLC (ER&amp;T) are regulated by the FERC. Through its subsidiaries, Power seeks to balance the output of its generating capacity, fuel requirements and supply obligations through integrated energy marketing and trading, enhance its ability to produce low-cost energy through efficient nuclear operations and pursue modest growth in the Region based on market conditions.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Power&#39;s objective is to enter into load-serving contracts, firm sales and trading positions sufficient to hedge at least 75% of its anticipated output over an 18-month to 24-month horizon. Power has achieved this objective through a combination of contracts related to the BGS auctions, contracts in Pennsylvania and Connecticut and other firm sales and trading positions. As mentioned above, in February 2005, the BPU approved the results of the BGS auction process for New Jersey customers. Power will continue to be a direct supplier of New Jersey EDCs under both the BGS-FP and BGS-CIEP auctions, entering into additional contracts that began on June&nbsp;1, 2005. Power believes that its obligations under these contracts are reasonably balanced by its available supply. Power continues to believe that hedging approximately
75% of its anticipated generation output is an appropriate way to reduce the volatility of its earnings.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>On May&nbsp;27, 2005, Power entered into an agreement to sell its electric generation facility located in Waterford, Ohio (Waterford) to a subsidiary of American Electric Power Company, Inc. (AEP). Since commencing construction of the project, the dramatic increase in natural gas prices relative to the price increase of coal and the failure to receive capacity compensation for the facility caused Power to consider alternatives for the project. After reviewing the alternatives in conjunction with other strategic and financial considerations, Power concluded that the value to be received from the sale of Waterford represented a means to accelerate the realization of the plant&#39;s value. The sale price for the facility and inventory is $220 million. The proceeds, together with anticipated reduction in tax liability, are
approximately $300 million, which will be used to retire debt at Power and PSEG. See Note&nbsp;3. Discontinued Operations, Dispositions and Acquisitions of the Notes for further discussion.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>During 2005 Power began collecting a monthly fixed payment amount for reliability services provided by its generating facilities in Connecticut, retroactive to November&nbsp;18, 2004. Based on a FERC order issued in late April 2005 and effective February&nbsp;24, 2005, subject to refund and hearing, Power will also receive payments for reliability services provided by the Sewaren Station, Units&nbsp;1, 2, 3 and 4 and Hudson Station, Unit 1. Such payments will be net of operating margins at the units.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Effective June&nbsp;1, 2005, Power retired its oil-fired, steam Units&nbsp;7 and 8 in Kearny, New Jersey as it no longer considered them to be economically viable and the PJM System Operator concluded that the units were no longer needed for system reliability.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>On July&nbsp;18, 2005, Power&#39;s new Bethlehem Energy Center, a 750 MW, natural gas-fired combined cycle power generation plant near Albany, New York, began commercial operations.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>A key factor in Power&#39;s ability to achieve its objectives is its capability to operate its nuclear and fossil stations at sufficient capacity to avoid the need to purchase higher-priced electricity to satisfy its obligations. Concurrently with the signing of the Merger Agreement, Power entered into an Operating Services Contract (OSC) with Exelon Generation, LLC (Exelon Generation). Under the terms of the OSC, since January&nbsp;17, 2005, Exelon Generation has provided management personnel and its proprietary management systems under a fee arrangement to Power to operate its nuclear generating facilities. In May 2005, a scheduled refueling outage at Salem Unit&nbsp;2 was completed ahead of schedule while meeting self-imposed nuclear safety targets.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Beyond 2005, Power believes that the rise in power prices over the past several years has created a favorable environment to enter into future power sales contracts. This should result in growth in gross margin, and should help support earnings growth over the next several years.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>For the six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2005, Power had Income from Continuing Operations of $171 million. Power expects Income from Continuing Operations to range from $335 million to $385 million</font></p>
<p align=center>54</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=left><font color=#000000>in 2005. This increase as compared to 2004 reflects anticipated improvements in Power&#39;s Nuclear and Fossil operations, anticipated higher margins as existing contracts expire, the realization of current and anticipated higher market prices and additional generation going into service. It is expected that these improvements will be partially offset by higher depreciation expense. For the six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2005, Power had a Net Loss of $19 million, which includes a Loss from Discontinued Operations of $190 million related to Waterford, discussed above. It is expected that costs associated with the proposed Merger could reduce 2005 results, which is not included in the earnings projection noted above.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Energy Holdings, through Global, owns and operates electric generation and distribution facilities in international and U.S. markets. The generation plants sell power under long-term agreements, as well as on a merchant basis, while the distribution companies are rate-regulated enterprises. Through Resources, Energy Holdings invests in energy-related financial transactions, including leveraged leases, which are designed to produce predictable earnings and cash flows.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>For the first half of 2005, Energy Holdings had Net Income of $101 million. Energy Holdings expects Income from Continuing Operations for 2005 to range from $135 million to $155 million reflecting improved results from Texas Independent Energy,&nbsp;L.P. (TIE), lower financing costs and the absence of foreign currency losses at Elektrocieplownia Chorzow Sp. z o.o. (ELCHO) which are expected to more than offset the loss of earnings due to the sale of Meiya Power Company Limited (MPC) and the partial sale of Luz del Sur S.A.A. (LDS) in 2004.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Global continues to limit its capital spending, while focusing on operations and improved performance of existing businesses and is seeking to opportunistically monetize investments that may no longer have a strategic fit. In April 2005, Global sold a 35% interest in Dhofar Power Company S.A.O.C. (Dhofar Power), reducing its ownership interest from 81% to 46%, through a public offering on the Omani stock exchange for net proceeds of approximately $25 million.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The capital requirements of Global&#39;s consolidated subsidiaries are primarily financed from internally generated cash flow within the projects and from local sources on a non-recourse basis or limited discretionary investments by Energy Holdings.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Resources is focused on maintaining its current investment portfolio and does not expect to make any new investments. Resources&#39; objective is to produce predictable cash flows, earnings and related tax benefits. Resources&#39; ability to realize tax benefits associated with its leveraged lease investments is dependent upon operating gains generated by its affiliates. Resources&#39; earnings and cash flows are expected to decrease in the future as the investment portfolio matures.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>In January 2005, Resources and Global sold their interests in three Solar Electric Generating Systems (SEGS) projects for proceeds of approximately $7 million and Resources received proceeds of approximately $17 million from the KKR Fund&#39;s sale of its investment in KinderCare Learning Centers, Inc. In June 2005, Resources wrote off its entire investment of approximately $15 million, net of tax, in an aircraft lease to United Airlines (UAL) upon termination of the lease and repossession of the aircraft by the lenders in a bankruptcy proceeding with UAL. As of June&nbsp;30, 2005, Resources&#39; gross investment in leased aircraft is approximately $36 million.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Resources continues to monitor credit concerns with respect to certain lessees in its portfolio. In addition, Resources is monitoring issues regarding the accounting and tax treatment of certain leases in its portfolio. For additional information, see Note 5. Commitments and Contingent Liabilities of the Notes.</font></p>
<p align=center>55</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>

<div align=left>
<p><font color=#000000><hr color=#000000 noshade align=left width=48 size=0></font></p>
</div>
<table  cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0 border=0><tr bgcolor=#ffffff>
<td align=right valign=top><font color=#000000>&nbsp;</font></td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td></tr>
<tr bgcolor=#ffffff>
<td align=right valign=top><font color=#000000>(A)</font></td>
<td align=left valign=bottom nowrap>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</td>
<td align=left valign=bottom><font color=#000000>Other activities include non-segment amounts of Energy Holdings and its subsidiaries and intercompany eliminations. Specific amounts include interest on certain financing transactions and certain other administrative and general expenses at Energy Holdings.</font></td></tr>
<tr bgcolor=#ffffff>
<td align=right valign=top><font color=#000000>&nbsp;</font></td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td></tr>
<tr bgcolor=#ffffff>
<td align=right valign=top><font color=#000000>(B)</font></td>
<td align=left valign=bottom nowrap>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</td>
<td align=left valign=bottom><font color=#000000>Other activities include non-segment amounts of PSEG (as parent company) and intercompany eliminations. Specific amounts include preferred securities dividends/preference unit distributions for PSE&amp;G and Energy Holdings, interest on certain financing transactions and Merger expenses and certain other administrative and general expenses at PSEG (as parent company).</font></td></tr>
<tr bgcolor=#ffffff>
<td align=right valign=top><font color=#000000>&nbsp;</font></td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td></tr>
<tr bgcolor=#ffffff>
<td align=right valign=top><font color=#000000>(C)</font></td>
<td align=left valign=bottom nowrap>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</td>
<td align=left valign=bottom><font color=#000000>Includes Discontinued Operations at Power in 2005 and 2004 and Energy Holdings in 2004. See Note&nbsp;3. Discontinued Operations, Dispositions and Acquisitions of the Notes.</font></td></tr>
<tr bgcolor=#ffffff>
<td align=right valign=top><font color=#000000>&nbsp;</font></td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td></tr>
<tr bgcolor=#ffffff>
<td align=right valign=top><font color=#000000>(D)</font></td>
<td align=left valign=bottom nowrap>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</td>
<td align=left valign=bottom><font color=#000000>Earnings per Share of any segment does not represent a direct legal interest in the assets and liabilities allocated to any one segment but rather represents a direct interest in PSEG&#39;s assets and liabilities as a whole.</font></td></tr>
</table>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $26 million or $0.11 per share decrease in Income from Continuing Operations for the quarter was primarily due to lower demand from commercial and industrial customers and higher operations and maintenance costs at PSE&amp;G, a $15 million, after-tax, write-off at Resources for its UAL lease</font></p>
<p align=center>56</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=left><font color=#000000>investment and lower gains realized on the Nuclear Decommissioning Trust Funds at Power. In addition, Merger-related costs of approximately $14 million, net of tax, at PSEG and Power and higher interest expense at the PSEG parent level contributed to the decline in Income from Continuing Operations. Partially offsetting the decreases were an overall improvement in operations at Power, reflecting less congestion and nuclear plant outage days in 2005 and improved earnings at Global from its South American distribution investments and stronger foreign currency exchange rates.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $16 million or $0.10 per share decrease in Income from Continuing Operations for the six months was primarily due to lower earnings at PSE&amp;G and Power, as discussed above, as well as to Merger-related costs of approximately $16 million, net of tax at PSEG and Power. Partly offsetting the decreases were higher earnings at Global due to improved operations and increased ownership at TIE, as well as the reasons discussed above, and the absence of a $17 million write-down in 2004 of the carrying value of the leveraged lease investment in the Collins generation facility at Resources which more than offset the $15 million write-off of the UAL lease investment in June 2005.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The decreases in Net Income for the quarter and six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2005 included changes of $175 million and $171 million, respectively, from the Loss from Discontinued Operations at Power for the sale of Waterford and a decrease of $5 million in both the second quarter and six month period ended June&nbsp;30, 2005 from Income from Discontinued Operations at Energy Holdings from the sale of its majority interest in Carthage Power Company in 2004.</font></p>

<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>PSEG&#39;s results of operations are primarily comprised of the results of operations of its operating subsidiaries, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings, excluding changes related to intercompany transactions, which are eliminated in consolidation and certain financing costs at the parent company. For additional information on intercompany transactions, see Note&nbsp;12. Related-Party Transactions of the Notes. For a discussion of the causes for the variances at PSEG in the table above, see the discussions for PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings that follow.</font></p>

<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Operating Revenues</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>PSE&amp;G has three sources of revenue: commodity revenues from the sales of energy to customers and in the PJM spot market; delivery revenues from the transmission and distribution of energy through its system; and other operating revenues from the provision of various services. The $23 million increase for the quarter ended June&nbsp;30, 2005, as compared to the same period in 2004, was due to an increase of $30 million in commodity revenues, described below, offset by a $7 million decrease in delivery revenues. The $25 million increase for the six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2005, as compared to the same period in 2004, was due to increases of $41 million in commodity revenues, described below, and $3 million in other operating revenues, primarily related to appliance service contracts, partially offset by a $19 million
decrease in delivery revenues.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Commodity</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>PSE&amp;G makes no margin on commodity sales as the costs are passed through to customers. The difference between costs and the amount provided by customers in revenues is deferred and collected from or returned to customers in future periods. Total commodity volumes and revenues are subject to market forces. Gas commodity prices fluctuate monthly for commercial and industrial customers and annually through the Basic Gas Supply Service (BGSS) tariff for residential customers. In addition, for residential gas customers, PSE&amp;G has the ability to adjust rates upward two additional times and downward at any time, if warranted, between annual BGSS proceedings. Electric commodity prices are set at the annual BGS auctions.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $30 million increase in commodity revenues for the quarter ended June&nbsp;30, 2005, as compared to the same period in 2004, was due to a $20 million increase in gas commodity revenues, due primarily to higher BGSS prices and a $10 million increase in electric commodity revenues, primarily due to increased prices.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $41 million increase in commodity revenues for the six months ended June 30, 2005, as compared to the same period in 2004, was due to a $49 million increase in gas commodity revenues, due primarily to higher BGSS prices, partially offset by an $8 million decrease in electric commodity revenues, primarily due to decreased prices.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Delivery</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $7 million decrease in delivery revenues for the quarter ended June&nbsp;30, 2005, as compared to the same period in 2004, was due to decreases of $4 million in electric revenues and $3 million in gas revenues. The $4 million decrease in electric delivery revenues was due primarily to lower volumes of $8 million offset by increased prices of $4 million due to increased Societal Benefits Clause (SBC) rates, primarily due to the Universal Service Fund (USF) component. The $3 million decrease in gas delivery revenues was primarily due to $4 million in lower rates due to the expiration of the Gas Cost</font></p>
<p align=center>58</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=left><font color=#000000>Underrecovery Adjustment (GCUA) clause in January 2005 and lower volume and demand revenues of $2 million. The GCUA rates are recorded with a corresponding offset in Energy Costs, described below. These decreases were offset by increased SBC revenues of $3 million, primarily due to the USF component. SBC rates are recorded with a corresponding offset in Operating Expenses, described below, resulting in no impact to Net Income.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $19 million decrease in delivery revenues for the six months ended June 30, 2005, as compared to the same period in 2004, was due to a $22 million decrease in gas delivery revenues, partially offset by a $3 million increase in electric delivery revenues. The $22 million decrease in gas delivery revenues was primarily due to lower volume and demand revenues of $26 million and $9 million in lower rates due to the expiration of the GCUA clause in January 2005. These decreases were offset by increased SBC revenues of $13 million, primarily due to the USF component, as described above. The $3 million increase in electric delivery revenues was due primarily to increased prices of $10 million due to increased SBC rates, primarily due to the USF component, offset by decreased volumes of $7 million.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Operating Expenses</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Energy Costs</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $29 million increase for the quarter ended June&nbsp;30, 2005, as compared to the same period in 2004, was comprised of increases of $18 million in electric costs and $11 million in gas costs. The electric increase is due to a $21 million increase related to higher prices for BGS and Non-Utility Generation (NUG) purchases partially offset by a $3 million decrease due to lower NUG volumes. The increase in gas costs was caused by a $19 million or 16% increase in gas prices offset by a $6 million decrease due to the expiration of the GCUA clause in January 2005, described above, and a $2 million decrease in sales volumes due primarily to lower interruptible sales.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $34 million increase for the six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2005, as compared to the same period in 2004, was comprised of increases of $32 million in gas costs and $2 million in electric costs. The increase in gas costs was caused by a $62 million or 7% increase in gas prices offset by a $20 million decrease due to the expiration of the GCUA clause in January 2005, described above, and an $8 million decrease in sales volumes due primarily to lower sales to cogenerators. The electric increase is due to increases of $12 million due to higher prices for BGS and NUG purchases and $5 million due to higher BGS volumes, partially offset by a decrease of $15 million due to lower NUG volumes.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Operation and Maintenance</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $10 million increase for the quarter ended June&nbsp;30, 2005, as compared to the same period in 2004, was due primarily to increased SBC expenses of $7 million and $6 million in labor and fringe benefits due to increased wages and staffing.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $27 million increase for the six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2005, as compared to the same period in 2004, was due primarily to increased SBC expenses of $22 million and $15 million in labor and fringe benefits due to increased wages and staffing. These were offset by decreases of $11 million in outside service costs due to lower regulatory charges and Demand Side Management expenses due to lower volumes.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Depreciation and Amortization</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $2 million increase for the quarter ended June&nbsp;30, 2005, as compared to the same period in 2004, was due primarily to a $2 million increase due to additional plant in service and a $2 million increase in the amortization of the Securitization regulatory asset offset by a $2 million decrease in software amortization.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $10 million increase for the six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2005, as compared to the same period in 2004, was due primarily to a $6 million increase in the amortization of the Securitization regulatory asset, a $4 million increase due to additional plant in service and a $2 million increase in the amortization of the Remediation Adjustment Clause (RAC). These were offset by a $2 million decrease in software amortization.</font></p>
<p align=center>59</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Interest Expense</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $5 million decrease for the quarter ended June&nbsp;30, 2005, as compared to the same period in 2004, was due to decreases of $8 million due to lower average interest rates and lower amounts of long-term debt outstanding. This was offset by increases of $2 million due to higher short-term interest rates and higher amounts of short-term debt outstanding.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $17 million decrease for the six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2005, as compared to the same period in 2004, was due to decreases of $20 million due to lower average interest rates and lower amounts of long-term debt outstanding. This was offset by increases of $4 million due to higher short-term interest rates and higher amounts of short-term debt outstanding.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Income Taxes</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $8 million decrease for the six months ended June 30, 2005, as compared to the same period in 2004, was primarily due to lower&nbsp;pre-tax income.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>Power</font></b></p>
<table width=100% cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0 border=0><tr bgcolor=#ffffff>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td align=center valign=bottom colspan=7><b><font color=#000000><small>For the<br>
Quarters&nbsp;Ended<br>

</table>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Operating Revenues</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $70 million increase for the quarter ended June&nbsp;30, 2005, as compared to the same period in 2004, was due to increases of $36 million in generation revenues, $23 million in gas supply revenues and $11 million in trading revenues.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $102 million increase for the six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2005, as compared to the same period in 2004, was due to increases of $15 million in generation revenues, $69 million in gas supply revenues and $18 million in trading revenues.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Generation</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The increase of $36 million in generation revenues for the quarter ended June&nbsp;30, 2005, as compared to the same period in 2004, was primarily due to an increase of approximately $27 million related to Reliability Must-Run (RMR) revenues which commenced in 2005 for certain of Power&#39;s generating facilities, combined with a net increase of approximately $9 million as revenues from new contracts and increased sales into the various power pools more than offset decreased revenues due to reduced load being served under the fixed-priced BGS contracts.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The increase of $15 million in generation revenues for the six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2005, as compared to the same period in 2004, was primarily due to an increase of approximately $34 million</font></p>
<p align=center>60</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=left><font color=#000000>related to RMR revenues. This increase was partially offset by a net decrease of approximately $19 million due to reduced load being served under the fixed-priced BGS contracts partially offset by revenues from new contracts and increased sales into the various power pools.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Gas Supply</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $23 million and $69 million increase in gas supply revenues for the quarter and six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2005, respectively, as compared to the same periods in 2004, was primarily due to higher gas prices under the BGSS contract partially offset by decreased sales volumes mainly due to lower demand by PSE&amp;G.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Trading</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $11 million and $18 million increase in trading revenues for the quarter and six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2005, respectively, as compared to the same periods in 2004, was primarily due to improved market conditions.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Operating Expenses</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Energy Costs</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Energy Costs represent the cost of generation, which includes fuel purchases for generation as well as purchased energy in the market, and gas purchases to meet Power&#39;s obligation under its BGSS contract with PSE&amp;G. The $11 million and $50 million increase for the quarter and six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2005, respectively, as compared to the same periods in 2004, was primarily due to higher prices for gas used to satisfy Power&#39;s BGSS obligations which were partially offset by decreased costs of generation primarily due to decreased congestion costs as compared to 2004.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Operation and Maintenance</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $1 million increase for the quarter ended June&nbsp;30, 2005, as compared to the same period in 2004, was primarily due to a $10 million restructuring charge recorded in June 2005 related to Nuclear&#39;s workforce realignment plan, partially offset by $6 million of lower real estate taxes. For additional information related to the restructuring charge, see Note&nbsp;5. Commitments and Contingent Liabilities of the Notes.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $1 million increase for the six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2005, as compared to the same period in 2004, was primarily due to a $10 million restructuring charge and higher costs of approximately $10 million related to Hope Creek&#39;s outage to complete Phase I of its turbine replacement in January 2005 and the Hope Creek outages for equipment repairs in March 2005 and June 2005. These increases were partially offset by $9 million of lower real estate taxes and $8 million of lower co-owner billings related to Power&#39;s jointly-owned facilities.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Depreciation and Amortization</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $6 million and $13 million increase for the quarter and six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2005, respectively, as compared to the same periods in 2004, was primarily due to the Lawrenceburg facility being placed into service in June 2004.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Other Income</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $43 million decrease in Other Income for each of the quarter and six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2005, as compared to the same periods in 2004, was primarily due to decreased realized gains related to the NDT Funds.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Other Deductions</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $5 million decrease for the quarter ended June 30, 2005, as compared to the same period in 2004, was primarily due to decreased losses and expenses related to the NDT Funds.</font></p>
<p align=center>61</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $11 million decrease for the six months ended June 30, 2005, as compared to the same period in 2004, was primarily due to a write-off of $4 million of unamortized issuance costs related to the extinguishment of non-recourse project financing related to the Lawrenceburg facility in the first quarter of 2004 and decreased losses and expenses related to the NDT Funds.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Interest Expense</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $4 million increase for the quarter ended June&nbsp;30, 2005, as compared to the same period in 2004, was primarily due to the Lawrenceburg facility being placed into service in June 2004 resulting in a decrease in capitalized interest.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $2 million increase for the six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2005, as compared to the same period in 2004, was primarily due to a reduction in capitalized interest related to Lawrenceburg, partially offset by lower interest rates on new long-term debt financing that replaced non-recourse project level financing.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Income Taxes</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $14 million and $13 million increase for the quarter and six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2005, respectively, as compared to the same periods in 2004, was primarily due to taxes related to higher&nbsp;pre-tax income and prior period adjustments recorded in 2004.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Loss from Discontinued Operations, including Loss on Disposal, net of tax</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>On May 27, 2005, Power reached an agreement to sell its Waterford generation facility for approximately $220 million and recognized a loss on disposal of approximately $177 million for the initial write-down of its carrying amount of Waterford to its fair value less cost to sell. It is anticipated that the transaction will close during the second half of 2005. See Note&nbsp;3. Discontinued Operations, Dispositions and Acquisitions of the Notes for additional information.</font></p>

<td align=right valign=bottom nowrap>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</td>
<td align=right valign=bottom nowrap><font color=#000000>$</font></td>
<td align=right valign=bottom><font color=#000000>(8</font></td>
<td align=left valign=bottom nowrap><font color=#000000>)</font></td>
<td align=right valign=bottom nowrap>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</td>
<td align=right valign=bottom nowrap><font color=#000000>$</font></td>
<td align=right valign=bottom><font color=#000000>(9</font></td>
<td align=left valign=bottom nowrap><font color=#000000>)</font></td>
<td align=right valign=bottom nowrap>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</td>
<td align=right valign=bottom nowrap><font color=#000000>$</font></td>
<td align=right valign=bottom><font color=#000000>(1</font></td>

<td align=left valign=bottom><p style='margin-left:1em;text-indent:-1em;'></p></td>

</table>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The variances in Operating Revenues, Energy Costs, Operation and Maintenance, Depreciation and Amortization and Income from Equity Method Investments were primarily attributed to Global&#39;s acquisition of the remaining interests in TIE, thus consolidating the entity effective July&nbsp;1, 2004 and Global&#39;s sale of a 35% interest in Dhofar Power through a public offering on the Omani Stock Exchange in April 2005, reducing its ownership interest to 46% and thus accounting for the investment under the equity method of accounting following the sale. For additional information, see Note&nbsp;3. Discontinued Operations, Dispositions and Acquisitions of the Notes.</font></p>
<p align=center>62</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Operating Revenues</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $150 million increase for the quarter ended June&nbsp;30, 2005, as compared to the same period in 2004, was due to higher revenues at Global of $180 million, including a $153 million increase related to the consolidation of TIE commencing July&nbsp;1, 2004, a $14 million increase related to Sociedad Austral de Electricidad S.A. (SAESA) in Chile due to higher energy sales volumes and a $9 million increase related to Electrownia Skawina S.A. (Skawina) in Poland due to higher energy sales in the spot market and higher Polish Zloty foreign exchange rate offset by an $11 million decrease related to the deconsolidation of Dhofar Power. Offsetting the increase were lower revenues at Resources of $29 million primarily due to a $22 million pre-tax write-off of its leveraged lease investment with UAL.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $316 million increase for the six months ended June 30, 2005, as compared to the same period in 2004, was due to higher revenues at Global of $322 million, including a $279 million increase related to the consolidation of TIE commencing July 1, 2004, a $24 million increase related to SAESA due to higher energy sales volumes and a $19 million increase related to Skawina due to higher energy sales in the spot market and higher Polish Zloty foreign exchange rates offset by a $12 million decrease related to the deconsolidation of Dhofar Power. Offsetting the increase were lower revenues at Resources of $6 million primarily due to a $22 million&nbsp;pre-tax write-off of its UAL Lease investment offset by a $17 million&nbsp;pre-tax charge recorded in 2004 to reduce the carrying value of the Collins lease.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Operating Expenses</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Energy Costs</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $137 million increase for the quarter ended June&nbsp;30, 2005, as compared to the same period in 2004, was primarily due to a $120 million increase related to the consolidation of TIE commencing July&nbsp;1, 2004, an $11 million increase related to SAESA due to significant increases in energy costs and a $6 million increase related to Skawina, offset by a $4 million decrease related to the deconsolidation of Dhofar Power.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $255 million increase for the six months ended June 30, 2005, as compared to the same period in 2004, was primarily due to a $219 million increase related to the consolidation of TIE commencing July&nbsp;1, 2004, a $21 million increase related to SAESA due to significant increases in energy costs and a $14 million increase related to Skawina, offset by a $4 million decrease related to the deconsolidation of Dhofar Power.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Operation and Maintenance</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $22 million increase for the quarter ended June&nbsp;30, 2005, as compared to the same period in 2004, was primarily due to a $17 million increase related to the consolidation of TIE commencing July&nbsp;1, 2004 a $5 million increase related to SAESA and a $2 million increase related to Skawina, offset by a $2 million decrease related to the deconsolidation of Dhofar Power.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $50 million increase for the six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2005, as compared to the same period in 2004, was primarily due to a $41 million increase related to the consolidation of TIE commencing July&nbsp;1, 2004, an $8 million increase related to SAESA and a $5 million increase related to Skawina, offset by a $1 million decrease related to the deconsolidation of Dhofar Power.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Depreciation and Amortization</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $2 million increase for the quarter ended June&nbsp;30, 2005, as compared to the same period in 2004, was primarily due to a $4 million increase related to the consolidation of TIE commencing July&nbsp;1, 2004 offset by a $2 million decrease related to the deconsolidation of Dhofar Power.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $6 million increase for the six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2005, as compared to the same period in 2004, was primarily due to a $9 million increase related to the consolidation of TIE commencing July&nbsp;1, 2004 offset by a $2 million decrease related to the deconsolidation of Dhofar Power.</font></p>
<p align=center>63</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Income from Equity Method Investments</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $3 million decrease for the quarter ended June&nbsp;30, 2005, as compared to the same period in 2004, was primarily due to a $2 million decrease related to the sale of Global&#39;s equity interest in MPC in December 2004, a $1 million decrease related to the consolidation of TIE commencing July&nbsp;1, 2004, offset by a $1 million increase related to the deconsolidation of Dhofar Power, thus accounting for the investment under the equity method of accounting following the sale of a 35% interest which reduced Global&#39;s investment to 46% in April 2005.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $6 million increase for the six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2005, as compared to the same period in 2004, was primarily due to a $3 million increase due to stronger results in South America, a $3 million loss recognized in the six months of 2004 from TIE, which was accounted for under the equity method of accounting until June&nbsp;30, 2004, and a $2 million increase related to the deconsolidation of Dhofar Power, thus accounting for the investment under the equity method of accounting following the sale, offset by a $2 million decrease related to the sale of Global&#39;s equity interest in MPC in December 2004.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Other Income</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $6 million increase for the quarter ended June&nbsp;30, 2005, as compared to the same period in 2004, was primarily due to foreign currency transaction gains of $8 million due to strengthening of the U.S. Dollar relative to the Polish Zloty on Global&#39;s investment in ELCHO, offset by a $1 million change in derivative fair value related to foreign exchange forwards at SAESA which expired in 2004.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $14 million increase for the six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2005, as compared to the same period in 2004, was primarily due to foreign currency transaction gains of $13 million due to strengthening of the U.S. Dollar relative to the Polish Zloty on Global&#39;s investment in ELCHO.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Interest Expense</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $5 million decrease for the quarter ended June&nbsp;30, 2005, as compared to the same period in 2004, was due to a $3 million decrease related to the deconsolidation of Dhofar Power and an $8 million decrease related to Resources, offset by a $5 million increase due to the consolidation of TIE commencing July&nbsp;1, 2004.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $2 million decrease for the six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2005, as compared to the same period in 2004, was due to a $4 million decrease related to the deconsolidation of Dhofar Power and an $8 million decrease related to Resources, offset by a $10 million increase due to the consolidation of TIE commencing July&nbsp;1, 2004.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Income Taxes</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $4 million and $9 million decrease for the quarter and six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2005, respectively, as compared to the same periods in 2004, was primarily due to a lower effective rate for Global due to a change in mix of domestic and international earnings.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Income from Discontinued Operations, including Gain on Disposal, net of tax</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>See Note 3. Discontinued Operations, Dispositions and Acquisitions of the Notes for additional information.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>Other</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>To supplement the Condensed Consolidated Financial Statements presented in accordance with accounting principles generally accepted in the U.S. (GAAP), PSEG and Energy Holdings use the non-GAAP measure of Earnings Before Interest and Taxes (EBIT).</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>PSEG&#39;s and Energy Holdings&#39; Management each reviews EBIT internally to evaluate performance and manage operations and believes that the inclusion of this non-GAAP financial measure provides consistent and comparable measures to help shareholders understand current and future operating</font></p>
<p align=center>64</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=left><font color=#000000>results. PSEG and Energy Holdings urge shareholders to carefully review the GAAP financial information included as part of this Quarterly Report.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Global</font></b></i></p>

<td align=left valign=top><font color=#000000>(A)</font></td>
<td align=left valign=top nowrap>&nbsp;</td>
<td align=left valign=top><font color=#000000>Total Capital at Risk includes Global&#39;s gross investments and equity commitment guarantees less non-recourse debt at the project level.</font></td></tr>
<tr bgcolor=#ffffff>
<td align=left valign=top><font color=#000000>(B)</font></td>
<td align=left valign=top nowrap>&nbsp;</td>
<td align=left valign=top><font color=#000000>For investments accounted for under the equity method of accounting, includes Global&#39;s share of net earnings, including Interest Expense and Income Tax Expense.</font></td></tr>
<tr bgcolor=#ffffff>
<td align=left valign=top><font color=#000000>(C)</font></td>
<td align=left valign=top nowrap>&nbsp;</td>
<td align=left valign=top><font color=#000000>Non-Recourse interest is Interest Expense on debt that is non-recourse to Global.</font></td></tr>
</table>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000><a name='Liquidity'>LIQUIDITY AND CAPITAL RESOURCES</a></font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The following discussion of liquidity and capital resources is on a consolidated basis for PSEG, noting the uses and contributions of PSEG&#39;s three direct operating subsidiaries, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>Operating Cash Flows</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSEG</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>For the six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2005, PSEG&#39;s operating cash flow decreased by approximately $260 million from $832 million to $572 million, as compared to the same period in 2004, due to net decreases from its subsidiaries as discussed below.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSE&amp;G</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>PSE&amp;G&#39;s operating cash flow decreased approximately $123 million from $179 million to $56 million for the six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2005, as compared to the same period in 2004, primarily due to higher funding for employee benefit plans and higher under recovery of SBC related costs.</font></p>
<p align=center>65</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Power</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Power&#39;s operating cash flow increased approximately $51 million from $377 million to $428 million for the six months ended June 30, 2005, as compared to the same period in 2004, due to decreased working capital needs offset by higher funding for employee benefit plans.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Energy Holdings&#39; operating cash flow decreased approximately $149 million from $298 million to $149 million for the six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2005, as compared to the same period in 2004, due primarily to the timing of tax benefits and payments associated with the termination of certain leases in 2004 and sales of certain Global investments in 2005.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>Common Stock Dividends</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Dividend payments on common stock for the quarters ended June&nbsp;30, 2005 and 2004 were $0.56 and $0.55 per share, respectively, and totaled approximately $133 million and $130 million, respectively. Dividend payments on common stock for the six months ended June 30, 2005 and 2004 were $1.12 and $1.10 per share, respectively, and totaled approximately $267 million and $260 million, respectively. Future dividends declared will be dependent upon PSEG&#39;s future earnings, cash flows, financial requirements, alternative investment opportunities and other factors. On July&nbsp;19, 2005, PSEG&#39;s Board of Directors approved a common stock dividend of $0.56 per share for the third quarter of 2005, reflecting an indicated annual dividend rate of $2.24 per share.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>Short-Term Liquidity</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>As of June 30, 2005, PSEG and its subsidiaries had a total of approximately $2.7 billion of committed credit facilities with approximately $1.9 billion of available liquidity under these facilities. In addition, PSEG and PSE&amp;G have access to certain uncommitted credit facilities. PSEG had $27 million outstanding and PSE&amp;G had $110 million outstanding under these uncommitted facilities as of June 30, 2005. All of the credit facilities below have been modified or structured to accommodate the potential</font></p>
<p align=center>66</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=left><font color=#000000>Merger with Exelon. Each of the facilities is restricted to availability and use to the specific companies as listed below.</font></p>

<tr bgcolor=#e5ffff>
<td align=left valign=top><p style='margin-left:1em;text-indent:-1em;'><b><u><font color=#000000>PSEG:</font></u></b></p></td>
<td bgcolor=#e5ffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td bgcolor=#e5ffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td bgcolor=#e5ffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td bgcolor=#e5ffff>&nbsp;</td>
